msDesc.head: Homiliary; Germany (Westphalia), 14th century, first quarter, with additions

msContents.summary: This homiliary was made for and partly by an as yet unidentified community of nuns in north-western Germany. It is unusual both for being restricted to the Christmas season and for its rich illumination. It falls into three sections. Fols. 1–102 (quires 1–13) contain material perhaps in liturgical order (although there are few rubrics) from the vigil of Christmas until Epiphany. Fols. 103–181 (quires 14–23) contain further Christmas sermons for unspecified occasions. Fols. 182–196 (quires 24–25) contain a mixture of Christmastide and Marian sermons.

msItem.author: Bernard of Clairvaux
msItem.title: Sermo VI in vigilia Natiuitatis Christi
msItem.incipit: Auditum audimus plenum gratia dignum accepcione
msItem.explicit: a terra omnia trahat ad se qui est benedictus in secular amen

msItem.author: Bernard of Clairvaux
msItem.title: Sermo IV in natiuitate Christi (?)
msItem.incipit: Tanta est fratres hodierna dominice natiuitatis sollempnitas, ut et spacium breue, et terre ei angusta sit latitudo
msItem.bibl: Cf. PL 183.126–7, text here varying considerably.

msItem.author: Rupert of Deutz
msItem.title: De divinis officiis III.12–13, De officio in vigilia natalis domini
msItem.incipit: Frequens et celeberriumum est
omnis caro salutare dei

msItem.author: Rupert of Deutz
msItem.title: De divinis officiis, III. 15–18
msItem.incipit: Illud quesitu dignum est

msItem.author: Rupert of Deutz
msItem.title: De divinis officiis, III.20–1, de officio primae missae in die natiuitatis domini
msItem.incipit: Prime misse officum dominus dixit

msItem.author: Ps.-Augustine
msItem.title: Serm. app. 123, in natali domini VII (extract)
msItem.incipit: Natiuitas domini nostri ihesu christi totum mundum

msItem.author: Jerome
msItem.title: Commentary on Matthew (extract, 1:1–3)
msItem.incipit: Liber generationis In Isaia legimus Generationem eius quis enarrabitur
In illo tempore. Exiit edictum a Cesare

msItem.author: Gregory I
msItem.title: Homiliae in Evangelia I.8.1
msItem.incipit: Quia largiente domino missarum sollempia ter hodie celebraturi sumus
In illo tempore. Pastores loquebantur ad inuicem
msItem.explicit: quod dominus ostendit nobis. Et reliqua.

msItem.author: Bede
msItem.title: Homeliae euangelii I.6, in aurora nativitatis domini

rubric.add: Omelia venerabilis Bede presbiteri de eadem lectione

msItem.incipit: Nato in Bethlehem domino saluatore
In principio erat uerbum

msItem.author: Bede
msItem.title: Homeliae euangelii I.7 (extract)
msItem.incipit: Quia temporalem mediatoris
msItem.explicit: cum ait, Et deus erat verbum

msItem.author: Gregory I
msItem.title: Hom. in Evangelia I.8.2
msItem.incipit: Regem hodie natum angelus nunciat, eiusque uoci angelorum chori concinunt, et congaudentes clamant Prius quippe quam redemptor noster per carnem nasceretur, discordiam cum angelis habuimus
msItem.explicit: quia propter te factus est deus homo qui cum patre etc

msItem.author: Leo
msItem.title: Sermo 21 c. 1, in natiuitate domini
msItem.incipit: Saluator noster dilectissimi hodie natus est gaudeamus

msItem.author: Augustine
msItem.title: Sermo 194, in natali domini xi
msItem.incipit: Audite filii lucis adoptati in regnum dei
msItem.explicit: agnoscamus presepe domini nostri ihesu christi

msItem.author: Honorius of Autun
msItem.title: Speculum ecclesiae: de nativitate domini
msItem.incipit: Letentur celi et exultet terra, iubilate montes laudem. Merito iubentur celi hodie letari
msItem.explicit: indeficientem lucem uocauit, qui cum patre

msItem.incipit: Sanctus et sollempnis dies fratres dilectissimi mundo hodie illuxit; exultemus et letemus in ea. Hodie sol uerus ortus est mundo, et hodie in tenebris lumen uerissimum ingressum est
msItem.explicit: Natus de spiritu sancto et Maria uirgine et regnat cum patre in seculo seculorum amen

msItem.author: Isidore
msItem.title: De ecclesiasticis officiis c. xxvi, De natali domini
msItem.incipit: Natalis domini dies. Dies ea de causa a patribus

msItem.author: Ambrose
msItem.title: Commentary on Luke II.55–7
msItem.incipit: Circumciditur itaque puer. Quis ille puer nisi ille de quo dictum est, Puer natus est nobis

msItem.author: Ps.-Maximus of Turin
msItem.title: Hom. xvi, de calendis Januariis
msItem.incipit: Quamuis non dubitem uos fratres karissimi
msItem.explicit: et uelut doctrine sue fructum paulus
msItem.bibl: CPL 220.16 (= CPL 219b); PL 57.255–8; Paul the Deacon I.37

msItem.author: Leo
msItem.title: Sermo xxii, in natiuitate domini II
msItem.incipit: Exultemus in domino, dilectissimi, et spirituali iocunditate letemur

msItem.author: Ps.-Maximus of Turin
msItem.title: Serm. IV, de nativitate domini I
msItem.incipit: Dominus noster iesus christus fratres karissimi, qui in eternum est cunctorum creator
msItem.explicit: non infirmitatis sed uirtutis, qui cum patre et spiritu

msItem.author: Augustine
msItem.title: Serm. 187, in natali domini IV
msItem.incipit: Laudem domini loquetur os meum
msItem.explicit: exultemus et iocundemur in eo, qui uiuit et regnat

msItem.author: Augustine
msItem.title: Serm. 200, in epiphania domini II, 1.1–2
msItem.incipit: Ad partum virginis adorandum, magi ab oriente uenerunt
msItem.explicit: ille natus est, cuius regnum non est de hoc seculo

msItem.author: Augustine
msItem.title: Serm. 200, in epiphania domini II, 1.2–3.4
msItem.incipit: Nobilitas fuit christi nascentis, in virginitate parientis; et nobilitas parientis in diuinitate nascentis
msItem.note: Text continues from the preceding item.

msItem.author: Gregory
msItem.title: Hom. in evangelia I.XI.6–7
msItem.incipit: Nato domino rege, aurum oferimus
msItem.explicit: amaricati redeamus, prestante domino nostro iesus christi qui cum patre

msItem.author: Ps.-Augustine
msItem.title: Serm. app. Caillau 17, in epiphania domini
msItem.incipit: Post miraculum virginei partus
msItem.explicit: quia ne deus in carne positus esset obscurus
msItem.bibl: CPL 371; ed. Caillau, Opera omnia, 24.1 pp. 403–405.14

msItem.author: Ps.-Augustine
msItem.title: Serm. app. Caillau 17, in epiphania domini
msItem.incipit: seruit et celum reddunt
msItem.explicit: post sepulchra uictores. Tu autem domine nostri miserere.
msItem.note: Continuing the previous item, but added in a later fourteenth century hand: quire 13 (fols. 96–102) is a later replacement. Ed. Caillau, Opera omnia, 24.1 pp. 405.14–409.3
Rest of fol. 100va blank. Fols. 100vb-101rb ruled, blank. Fol. 101v-102r blank. Fol. 102va-b ruled, blank.

msItem.author: Augustine
msItem.title: Serm. 186, in natali domini III
msItem.incipit: Gaudeamus hodie et letemur, et exultent gentes. Diem istum preclarissimum
msItem.note: PL 38.999–1000, ending incomplete through loss of one leaf after fol. 105.

msItem.incipit: ut libenti animo sermones
msItem.explicit: in ista festa temporalia quandoque cum angelis celebretis in secula amen
msItem.note: Cento: begins imperfect through loss of leaf before fol. 106, as Ps.-Augustine, Serm. 117 (PL 39.1977), followed at fol. 106va by Honorius of Autun's Speculum ecclesiae (PL 172.815 'Hodie namque rex celorum ... angelis sociare', PL 172.819 'Hec nativitas singularis ...' )

msItem.incipit: Predicemus hodie, Natum ex Maria Virgine saluatorem infantem in presepio positum, cum uigilantibus pastoribus moniti cum angelis adoremus
msItem.explicit: sicut omne genus uirorum, adam nouus recuparar dominus noster ihesus christus qui cum patre
msItem.note: Cento: extract from Ps.-Augustine, Serm. app. 121 ( CPL 368.121, PL 39.1987) followed (fol. 108va) by an extract from Ps.-Fulgentius of Ruspe, serm. 36, beg. 'Facta est Maria fenestra celi...' (PL 65.899B-900).

msItem.author: Quodvultdeus
msItem.title: Sermo contra iudaeos XI.1-XIV.9
msItem.incipit: Vos inquam conuenio o iudei, qui usque in hodiernum diem negastis filium dei

msItem.title: Sermo 'Eterni numinis'
msItem.incipit: Eterni numinis virgineum partum
msItem.explicit: qui utrumque in se retinet iesus christus qui cum
msItem.bibl: A cento; for details of the sources see Grégoire, Homéliaires (1980), p. 140 (Alan of Farfa I 3a-c)

msItem.author: Augustine
msItem.title: Sermo 188, in natali domini V
msItem.incipit: Filii dei sicut est equalis et coeternus

msItem.author: Leo
msItem.title: Serm. 27, in nativitate domini VII
msItem.incipit: Fesitiuitati hodierne dilectissimi uenerator uerus et pius est cultor
msItem.explicit: apparebitis cum ipso in gloria amen

msItem.author: Leo
msItem.title: Serm. 28, in nativitate domini VIII
msItem.incipit: Cum semper nos dilectissimi gaudere in domino
msItem.explicit: redempti peruenimus ad patriam nostram, in qua ipse gloriose uiuit et regnat deus in secula a

msItem.author: Ps.-Augustine
msItem.title: Serm. app. 121, in natali domini V
msItem.incipit: Quis tantarum rerum uerborumque copia instructus existat, qui huius sacratissime diei gratiam dignis possit laudibus predicare
msItem.explicit: quia ipse est splendor et gloria eterna, dominus noster iesus christus, cui est honor et gloria in secula seculorum amen

msItem.incipit: Cantate domino canticum nouum; quia mirabilia fecit. Nouus homo uenit in mundum; nouum canticum intulit mundo. Canticum illud leticie et exultationis, quod dudum auditum erat a pastoribus
msItem.note: ut digni sumus cum ceteris sanctis, hic et in futuro ei cantare canticum nouum Amen

msItem.author: Augustine
msItem.title: Sermo 369, de natiuitate domini I
msItem.incipit: Saluator noster natus de patre sine die

msItem.author: Augustine
msItem.title: Sermo 195, in natali domini XII
msItem.incipit: Filius dei idemque filius hominis dominus noster iesus christus sine matre de patre natus

msItem.note: Cento, as Gregoire, 228 no. 16 (=Alan of Farfa, I.2b-e, Gregoire 139–40, although the analysis there differs in some details from that presented here)

msItem.incipit: Audiat in presenti dilectio uestra fratres karissimi queadmodum ysaias propheta
msItem.note: Petrus Chrysologus, Serm. 145 (PL 52.589–91) = (Ps.-?) Augustine, Serm. Caillau I 6

msItem.incipit: Hodie fratres karissimi hesternum debemus reddere sermonem
Fratres dilectissimi scriptum est rorate celi desuper et nubes pluant iustum. Ueniat angelus, prediecet uerbum, aperiatur terra
Hodie ergo peperit uirgo maria eum qui filios dei faceret
Deus ab angelis proditur et agnus pastoribus demonstratur
msItem.explicit: ut redderet fratres; sic amauit ut faceret heredes iesus christus dominus noster qui cum patre et spiritu sancto uiuit et
msItem.note: Ps.-Augustine, Serm. Mai 176 (Mai, Nova Patrum Bibliotheca I, 397); a variant of Ps.-Augustine, Serm. app. 121 (PL 47.1229–31)

msItem.incipit: Hodie per totum mundum mellifui facti sunt celi; quia ad salutem nostram ex utero uirginis natus est filius dei. Hodie nobis de celo pax uera descendit. Ipse enim vere est pax uera qui fecit utraque unum, quoniam sua sanctissima natiuitate concordauit totum mundum
msItem.explicit: pacem terris redditam denunciat, qui cum patre et spiritu sancto uiuit et regnat

msItem.author: Ps.-Maximus of Turin
msItem.title: Sermo 11, de natiuitate Domini vi
msItem.incipit: Iustissime fratres festiuitate presentis diei in omne se gaudium
msItem.explicit: honore debito misteria semper christi uirtutesque laudemus
msItem.note: CPL 220.11 (= CPL 219b); PL 57.243–8; Paul the Deacon I.20.

msItem.author: Ps.-Maximus of Turin
msItem.title: Sermo 10, de natiuitate Domini V
msItem.incipit: Hodie christus natus est nos renati. Hodie saluator mundi per matrem nascendi tempus accepit
msItem.note: CPL 220.10 (= CPL 219b); PL 57.241–4; Paul the Deacon I.21.

msItem.incipit: Fratres karissimi, domini natalem celebrandum indicat tempus annuale, mundo gaudium instat generale

msItem.author: Fulgentius
msItem.title: Sermo 2
msItem.incipit: Cupientes aliquid de huius sacratissimi diei sollempnitate narrare
msItem.explicit: in fide et caritate custodiat idem deus et dominus noster amen

msItem.author: Ps.-Maximus of Turin
msItem.title: Sermo 13, de natiuitate domini vii
msItem.incipit: Hodierni misterii sacramentum, fratres karissimi, sicut credidistis et semper creditis, reparacio est salutis humane
msItem.note: CPL 220.13 (= CPL 219b); PL 57.249; Paul the Deacon I.23.
Rest of fol. 181ra-b blank; fol. 181v blank, ruled.

msItem.author: Hildebert of Le Mans
msItem.title: Sermo 55, in festo annutiatione, de incarnatione
msItem.incipit: Audita feci tibi noua, et signata sunt que nescis. Uerba sunt spiritus sancti in uisione sancto ysaie loquentis
Volens deus perditum mundum reparare, et seductum famulum celo reuocare, misit unigenitum hostem debellare
msItem.explicit: et sacrum spiramen in diuina specie contemplemur amen

msItem.author: Hildebert of le Mans
msItem.title: Sermo 5, in adventu domini V
msItem.incipit: Egrediemini filii syon Et ego si linguis hominum loquar et angelorum tamen in irritum cedet labor meus
msItem.explicit: morte uiuere sempiterne. A qua nos liberet iesus
msItem.note: PL 171.364–8 (= PL 198.1772, as Peter Comestor, serm. 19) slightly abbreviated.

msItem.incipit: Surge propera amica mea, columba mea, formosa mea. Tu amica mea per humilitatem, columba mea per caritatem, formosa mea per castitatem. Tu contra deum non tumuisti
In lectulo meo per noctem quesiui, quem diligit anima mea. Hoc senciunt amici

msItem.note: Rest of fol. 194va blank; 194vb blank except for the rubric for following item.

msItem.incipit: Quia uenerabilem diem assumptionis sancte marie genitricis dei columus, fratres karissimi, dignum et iustum est ut in domino gaudeamus, et spiritali iocunditate exultemus
msItem.explicit: et macula non est in te. Tu autem domine.
msItem.note: Rest of fol. 196v blank. Fol. 197r-v (early paper endleaf) blank.

supportDesc.extent: i (early paper endleaf) + 197 + i (early paper endleaf) 310 220
supportDesc.collation: 1(8) (fols. 1–8; the outer bifolium a later replacement), 2(8)-12(8) (fols. 9–95 including 60a, 60b) | 13(8–1: 6 canc.) (fols. 96–102: this quire is a late-fourteenth-century replacement) | 14(8–1: 4 missing with loss of text) (fols. 103–109), 15(8)-23(8) (fols. 110–181) | 24(8) (fols. 182–189), 25(8–1: 8 canc.) (fols. 190–6). Quires numbered in roman on the final verso, often more than once; the numberings suggest that quires 24–25 once followed or were intended to follow quire 13.

layoutDesc.layout: Usually 2 columns of 15 lines, ruled space 180–5 140
Fols. 166–181 (quires 22–23) 17–19 lines, ruled space 195–210 140 , partly above top line
Fols. 182–196 (quires 24–25): 20 long lines, ruled space 220 140 , above top line, except for fols. 195–6, below top line, so 19 lines.

handDesc.handNote: The main text was written in textualis formata by several hands, often to be distinguished only with difficulty; a full analysis is not attempted here.
Fols. 96ra-100va added by one hand in textualis formata, later fourteenth century.

decoDesc.summary: "Important, fine and good miniatures, fine borders, historiated and other initials, many with fleuronnée work." (Pächt and Alexander i. 136, pl. X).
decoDesc.decoNote: Space for initials not filled in.

decoNote.p: The decoration, which is unfinished, was carried out in several campaigns. The more finished decoration is found in seven quires and comprises borders (in different styles), historiated initials and flourished initials by three professional illuminators. The first professional artist worked in quire 1 (fols. 2–7); his work has also been identified by Oliver in Baltimore, Walters Art Museum W. 148. The second artist, who is sometimes compared with the Willehalm Master, worked in the second quire (fols. 9–16). The remaining professional decoration is attributed to a third artist (styled by Dorothy Miner the 'Master of Douce 185' and by Oliver the 'Jesse Master'). He and assistants were responsible for the outer bifolium of the first quire and for quires 5–7, 14–15 and 20.

This decoration was supplemented by borders, historiated and decorated initials, and flourished and coloured initials added by a number of less skilled artists, assumed to be the nuns themselves, with noticeable differences in style and approach between quires.

For more detailed discussion, to which the present description is indebted, see Judith Oliver, ‘Too Many Cooks? The Multiple Hands in a German Convent Homilary (Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS. Douce 185)’, in Manuscripts Changing Hands, ed. by Corine Schleif and Volker Schier, Wolfenbütteler Mittelalter-Studien, 31 (Wiesbaden: Harrossowitz Verlag in Kommission, 2016); and Judith Oliver, ‘Christmas Lessons in Word and Image in the Douce Homiliary’, Studies in Iconography, 37 (2016).

list.note: Quire 1, fols. 1–8: historiated initial; borders; spaces left for 1-line flourished initials (except on fol. 8r-v where they are supplied)
list.item: (fol. 1v) Full-page historiated initial A: Tree of Jesse

list.note: Quire 2, fols. 9–16: historiated initial, borders, 1-line flourished initials.
list.item: (fol. 12v) Historiated initial T, occupying two-thirds of the page: Annunciation

list.note: Quires 3 and 4, fols. 17–32: later miniature and historiated initials; spaces for 1-line initials partly filled in with later coloured initials in red and blue.
list.item: (fol. 17v) Miniature, one column: Angel with scroll ('Cras egrediemini ...'); below, prophet with scroll ('Paratus esto Israel...'); below, crowd of Israelites
(fol. 23v) Historiated initial I, filling one column: priest at lectern
(fol. 31v) 7-line historiated initial P: Mass, the elevation of the host, with hand blessing above

list.note: Quires 5–7, fols. 33–56: borders, historiated and decorated initials, 1-line flourished initials, and a more elaborate flourished initial on fol. 48ra (four lines). Gables added later to the borders in quire 5.
list.item: (fol. 33r) 7-line historiated initial S: the Visitation
(fol. 35v) Full-page historiated initial N: Nativity (above), Education of the Virgin in the Temple (below); two nuns to left
(fol. 37v) 7-line historiated initial L: Adoration of the Magi
(fol. 38r) 8-line historiated initial I, filling half the column: Isaiah
(fol. 39r) 7-line historiated initial E: Angel (above), Emperor Augustus (below)
(fol. 39v) Historiated initial Q filling two-thirds of the page: Presentation (above); Christ in the Temple (below)
(fol. 41v) 8-line decorated initial I (half the column width), interlace pattern on gold ground.

(fol. 42r) 8-line historiated initial N: two angels above, and one to the left, with three haloed figures (possibly also angels), one kneeling, all with scrolls; probably the 'multitudo celestium agminum que gloriam deo caneret' described in Bede's sermon (cf. Oliver, 'Christmas lessons' 122 for a slightly different interpretation.)
(fol. 44r) 9-line historiated initial I (half the column width): John the Evangelist with his eagle
(fol. 44v) Historiated initial Q filling two-thirds of the page: Virgin and child enthroned, with angels and two nuns.
(fol. 49va) 7-line historiated initial S: Nativity
(fol. 51va) 9-line historiated initial A: upper compartment, two midwives offering the Virgin food ; lower compartment, bathing the Christ child; kneeling nun to the right side of the letter.
(fol. 56va) 7-line historiated initial L: king enthroned with three vases
Quire 8, fols. 57–63: 1-line coloured initials added, incompletely; spaces left for larger initials on fols. 60brb (sketch for a decorated initial added), 63vb.

list.note: Quire 9, fols. 64–71: later borders; later historiated and decorated initials; later 1-line flourished and decorated initials.
list.item: (fol. 64r) 7-line historiated initial N: identified by Oliver as prophets' vision of incarnation
(fol. 65v) Historiated initial C filling two-thirds of the page: Nativity
(fol. 67v) 6-line decorated initial Q: gold interlace pattern on red and blue ground

list.note: Quire 10, fols. 72–9: later historiated initial; later 1-line coloured initials, fols. 72r-75r and 79v
list.item: (fol. 77va) 6-line historiated initial D: Virgin and Child
Quire 11, fols. 80–7: coloured initials added in places; 9-line space for a larger initial, fol. 82ra, with preparatory sketch.

list.note: Quire 12, fol. 88–95: later historiated initials; later 3-line initials in gold; 1-line coloured initials added sporadically
list.item: (fol. 88rb) 6-line historiated initial A: adoration of the Magi
(fol. 93v) Full-page historiated initial P: adoration of the Magi
Quire 13, fols. 96–102: coloured 1-line initials.

list.note: Quires 14–15, fols. 103–117: borders, historiated initials, 1-line flourished initials, with larger and more elaborate flourished initials in gold, red, and blue, sometimes with purple and green, on fols. 108rb, 109va, 111vb, 113ra, 114rb, 115vb
list.item: (fol. 103r): 7-line historiated initial G: vision of the Virgin and child in a star, seen by a prophet and three singing clerics.
(fol. 110v): 5-line historiated initial U: prophet

list.note: Quires 16–19, fols. 118–149: later large and elaborate flourished initials in gold, red and blue, fols. 121va, 125rb, 128rb, 131vb, 135va, 147rb; later decorated initial; 1-line coloured initials added, incompletely.
list.item: (fol. 143v) 7-line decorated initial S: dragon-human hybrid on gold ground.

list.note: Quire 20, fols. 150–157: borders, historiated initials, 1-line flourished initials.
list.item: (fol. 150r): 7-line historiated initial A: the Virgin nursing the Christ child with kneeling nun.

list.note: Quires 21–23, fols. 158–181: later historiated initial; later large and elaborate flourished initials in gold, red, and blue, fols. 158vb, 167vb, 171rb, 173rb; 1-line coloured initials added, incompletely; unfilled 9-line space for an initial, fol. 179ra.
list.item: (fol. 163r): 9-line historiated initial I: bishop (possibly Fulgentius)

list.note: Quires 24–25, fols. 182–196: later historiated and decorated initials; 1-line coloured letters added, incompletely.
list.item: (fol. 182r): historiated initial A filling two-thirds of the page: angel with prophets (Isaiah and Jeremiah)
(fol. 186r): 7-line decorated initial V
(fol. 190v): 9-line historiated initial E: King Solomon (above), crowd of nuns (below)
(fol. 193r): 8-line historiated initial S: Annuciation (?): angel (above), woman reading on seat (below)
(fol. 193v): 7-line decorated initial: grotesque (bird with female head) on gold ground.
(fol. 195r): historiated initial Q filling two-thirds of the page: death and assumption of the Virgin.

binding.p: Sixteenth-century binding; blind-tooled white leather over boards, sewn on four double/split bands, with two clasps.

history.provenance: Earlier scholarship localized the volume on art-historical grounds to the upper Rhine or area of Lake Constance (Pacht and Alexander i.136; Douce Legacy no. 242), but it is now associated with Westphalia, partly because of its relationship to Baltimore, Walters Art Museum, MS. W. 148 (see below) and partly because of stylistic similarities between the 'Jesse master' and contemporary painting from Cologne. Dating to the first quarter of the fourteenth century is suggested by Oliver on art-historical grounds.

The volume was written and decorated for and/or by a community of nuns illustrated at various points in the manuscript, whose habit included a white wimple with a single red cross. General parallels for such crosses have been found among Cistercian and Premonstratensian nuns in parts of Germany, with Oliver suggesting a close parallel with the depiction of Augustinian canonesses in a gradual from Erfurt ('Christmas lessons', 127–8).

The manuscript is probably a companion volume to Baltimore, Walters Art Museum, MS. W.148, an illustrated homiliary for Eastertide. Both volumes have sixteenth-century bindings in identical style; they share an artist; and they are closely comparable in format and script.
Francis Douce, 1757–1834: bought by him in June 1831 from Payne and Foss (see Douce Legacy, no. 242); price '15.15.0' on fol. ii verso.

recordHist.source: Description by Matthew Holford, Feb. 2021. Previously described in the Summary Catalogue. Summary Catalogue, vol. 4, p. 547

availability.p: To ensure its preservation, access to this item is restricted, and readers are asked to work from reproductions and published descriptions as far as possible. If you wish to apply to see the original, please click the request button above. When your request is received, you will be asked to contact the relevant curator outlining the subject of your research, the importance of this item to that research, and the resources you have already consulted.

ref.title: Manuscripts from German-Speaking Lands – A Polonsky Foundation Digitization Project

listBibl.head: Printed descriptions:
listBibl.bibl: S. J. P. van Dijk, Latin Liturgical Manuscripts in the Bodleian Library, Oxford, vol. 2: Office Books (typescript, 1957), p. 163b

revisionDesc.change: New draft description for Polonsky German digitization project.

Mitch Fraas Provenance and acquisition information added using https://github.com/littlegustv/oxfordupdates/blob/master/test_case_for_oxford_prov.rb in collaboration with the Mapping Manuscript Migrations project.
James Cummings Up-converted the markup using https://github.com/jamescummings/Bodleian-msDesc-ODD/blob/master/convertTolkien2Bodley.xsl
